title: How to write a feedback report - Quora

response.answer_text: Sample reports like this tell employers so much more about the potential employee than whether or not they are capable of performing the task of writing a report. Report writing—especially when considering feedback about a product, a retail purchase or dining experience—usually comes with an entire set of rules that tend to be specific to each individual client’s way of doing things. General things to remember are also the most important. Above all else remain objective in your evaluations. Stick to reporting facts and backing them up with observations. Unless specifically asked, do not include anything subjective in nature—in other words this type of report is seldom interested in your feelings or opinions. The reports I write most often are for service industry companies (restaurants, bars and casinos for the most part) and a report typical of my experience might go something like this: I arrived at Joe’s Bar and Grill at 7:13 PM on Friday the 18th of June and was immediately greeted by the hostess, named Gretchen. She was approximately 5′7″ in height, had shoulder-length blonde hair that she wore in a pony tail, green eyes and a nose-ring in her left nostril. Gretchen was wearing the standard Joe’s Bar and Grill uniform consisting of a black skirt, white blouse and black necktie. Gretchen made eye-contact as soon as I entered the establishment, greeted me by saying, “Hi! Welcome to Joe’s, I’ll be right with you, ok?” She maintained eye contact until I indicated I didn’t mind waiting and after thanking me, she turned her attention back to the telephone that I didn’t realize had been on HOLD when I walked in. At 7:20 PM a gentleman standing approximately 6 feet tall with a shaved head, metal-rimmed eyeglasses and a dark brown goatee leaned into the waiting area from what I thought was likely the bar and without looking away from the television screen above the bar asked me (I thought) if I wanted a beer while I waited for, “Gretch to stop her yacking.” I was unsure if the gentleman was an employee because he was wearing faded blue jeans that were fraying at the cuffs, black motorcycle boots and a blue T-shirt, the sleeves of which had been removed. Unsure if who he was or to whom he was speaking, I hesitated but before I could ask him to clarify, he mumbled something I couldn’t understand and returned to the end of the bar where he sat on a stool that was situated even with the bar itself—neither behind it where I might assume he was an employee, nor on the “customer” side of the bar where one might assume he was simply an overly-friendly patron. While I’d offer this as a very basic example of objective report writing, I can tell you as someone who uses these assignments when deciding which candidates I might offer a position, almost automatically I will end up hiring the person that took the time to ask me to specify exactly what my needs and expectations were for this project and then repeated them back to me. THAT very small trait is more memorable than the most perfectly written report you can imagine because that candidate took the time to show me the importance he place on making sure he understood my needs and didn’t presume he could read my mind.

Your report should be 3–4 din a-4size pages and include details on the following: Divide the report into three main sections and add a cover page.Include necessary information in these three main section and save the cover page for the summary information.Lists and charts which reflects area of strength and area of improvement.On basis of that , write the necessary information of recommendations , but don't add too much information , try to be smart.After that, summarize the information and write them in the cover page .you can add photos also to make it better.I hope, this will help you to write a feedback report.

It would be better to write in the first person. Make it structured, in the way they have suggested, using their headings. But, make it personal, conversational and compelling. Something like this: Approach I was asked to review your digital channels and so I approached it by taking each in turn and applying the following tests: What was the content? Was it informative? Etc Results Here are my findings: Channel One Strengths Improvements Recommendations You could probably have a conclusion section and sometimes it is better to put that at the top so that they know up front what you think of them. I hope this helps.
